As a new Software Dev/Engineer, don't be so salary oriented or short-sighted. Your main focus should be on upskilling and future-proofing your self. The tech industry rapidly changes and you want to be as competitive as possible. #100DaysOfCode
Tip 247 - Test your code - Tests are important. Unit tests, regression tests, integration tests, end-to-end tests. Test your code and your product will be much more stable. #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie
Tip 245 - Be supportive - Try and support your team members whether that's by attending an important presentation or helping them if they get stuck. #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie
Tip 241 - Have your team's back - Good teams have each other’s backs. This creates a safe space to try new things without fear of retribution. #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie

Learn #JavaScript

You can build server-side apps
You can build mobile apps
You can build frontend apps
You get to build desktop apps
. #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie

Did my CompSci degree help me?

Maybe it helped my CV

But I’ll tell you what...

Every technology I’ve ever needed for work I taught myself outside of university. #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie

The route to becoming a web dev:

* HTML / CSS tutorial
* Build webpage in HTML / CSS
* JavaScript tutorial
* JavaScript challenges on codewars
* Small web app
* React / Angular / Vue tutorial
* Small web app with chosen library #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie

I don’t see why frontend devs make a lot of money, all they need to know is:

JavaScript, HTML, CSS, React, TypeScript, GraphQL, NodeJS, command line, Git, webpack, AWS, Jest, Enzyme, Docker, Jenkins, Selenium, performance tuning

🤣🤣🤣 #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie

Tip 216 - Clarify requirements before starting - You should understand the acceptance criteria before delving into writing the code. It will save you time and pain later down the line. #100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie

As a developer/engineer make sure you are always communicating with your manager, chances are they’ll underestimate the time needed to carry out certain tasks especially if they are not coders themselves. #100DaysOfCode #coding

Tip 162 - I love doing side projects even if I’m in a permanent role. Side projects allow you to learn new things, they're great for your CV and most importantly keep your skills up-to-date. #100DaysOfCode #coding

Tip 159 - Don’t be afraid to look at somebody else’s code and try to understand it.  If you're on a project with senior talent, this is a great opportunity to take advantage of!  Don’t be afraid to ask about things you don’t understand in their code. #100DaysOfCode #coding
Tip 156 - If software cannot be maintained then it will be rewritten – Dave Cheney #100DaysOfCode #coding

I've have some JS notes I have been making over the last few months. I will rewrite and collate them over the next few days, before publishing on GitHub if anyone is interested. 

#100DaysOfCode #JavaScript #Coding #tech

Tip 151 - Learn how to learn - Everyone learns best in different ways. Some learn best from reading books and others like following video tutorials. If you figure out your learning style and use it, you'll have a much easier time learning new things. #100DaysOfCode #coding

Tip 101 - If you're committed to learning a programming language. Learn the most important libraries for your use cases. The more libraries you’re aware of the less likely you are to try reinventing the wheel. #100DaysOfCode #coding

Tip 76 - There isn't a right answer for what programming language to learn first; however, some will be easier to pick up. My top two are Python and JavaScript because they have a large community behind them and the syntax is relative straight-forward.#100DaysOfCode #coding

I wrote a Node.js program that grabs overdue items in your todo list and calls and/or texts you reminding you of the tasks.
Here's a snippet below. I'll release the full thing later as editing is long.
#100DaysOfCode #Node https://t.co/ptM3jIIhce
Tip 46 - Take pride in what you build but be ready to have it replaced by someone or even yourself. Don't attach ego to your code. #100DaysOfCode #coding
Tip 45 - Be aware that the only constant in the tech (& programming) world is change: be open to it, accept it and dont look at it as some serious inconvenience to be fought! #100DaysOfCode #coding
Tip 44 - As you progress on your journey as a new programmer you may wonder if you should be taking notes. Yes you should! Taking notes by hand is best for long-term retention. #100DaysOfCode #coding
NPM install be like..... #100DaysofCode #coding #javascript https://t.co/4v1aj2TwTH

Tip 21 - YAGNI: You Aint Gonna Need It. Don't write code that you think you might need in future but don't need yet. This is coding for imaginary future use cases and inevitably the code will become dead code. #100DaysOfCode #coding

Tip 18 - Don't Try To Learn Everything - Although it's important to be constantly picking up on new things you only have so many hours in your day. So be selective of what you spend your time trying to learn. #100DaysOfCode #coding
Tip 12 - Look for existing solutions. Most of the time every problem you are struggling with is a problem that thousands of people have already faced and probably solved.  #100DaysOfCode #coding
Tip 5 - Name variables so that other developers can understand your code better. This is a skill you need to nurture. #100DaysOfCode #coding
Tip 4 - Always write code as if the person who ends up maintaining it will be a violent psychopath who knows where you live. #100DaysOfCode #coding
